awd_titl_txt: New Development in Point Process Theory, Methods and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
With the rapid development of modern data collection technologies, high-resolution spatial, temporal, and spatial-temporal data have become available at an unprecedented speed in recent years. The complexity and magnitude of these new data call for new statistical modeling tools. The proposed research will develop new modeling tools that can be used to analyze complex and large data.  Novel applications of the proposed methods will be considered to answer scientific questions arising in disciplines such as epidemiology, finance, and sociology.

This project will develop new theory and methods in point processes. In particular, the project will develop (1) more efficient estimation procedures based on quasi-likelihood to fit point process models and (2) a novel framework to conduct principle component analysis for marked point processes. For the first aim, efficient computational algorithms will be developed and theoretical properties of these algorithms will be investigated. For the second aim, the marks and points of the marked point process are linked through two potentially correlated latent processes, and principle component analysis is conducted for each of the two latent processes. Theoretical properties of the proposed method will be investigated. Data driven procedures will be developed to select the tuning parameters.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
With the rapid development of modern data collection technologies, high-resolution spatial, temporal, and spatial-temporal data have become available at an unprecedented speed in recent years. Such data commonly arise in many distinct areas such as business, criminology, ecology, epidemiology and social sciences. The complexity and magnitude of these new data call for new statistical modeling tools. The proposed research develops new tools that can be used to analyze these complex and large data. In particular, the project develops more efficient estimation procedures to fit point process models and a novel framework for conducting principle component analysis for marked point processes, both of which are appropriate for modeling high-resolution spatial, temporal, and spatial-temporal data. This project results in two publications in top tier statistical journals, including one at Journal of the American Statistical Association (JASA), and three manuscripts, including one revised for JASA (minor revision) and another one in revision for JASA.

The proposed methodologies have also been applied to many scientific research areas. In an ecological application, we model the spatial distribution of tropical rain forest tree species using a point process model and propose a more efficient model fitting procedure using quasi-likelihood. The fitted model can be used to help explain tropical rain forest tree species diversity by linking the spatial distributions of the tree species to environmental variables such as topographical variables and soil nutrient variables. In two applications involving street crime data, we use both parametric and semiparametric point process models to model the spatial distributions of different types of street crimes, in relation to a suite of potentially relevant variables such as socio-demographic variables and distances to the nearest alcohol outlet, police station, metro train station, and bus stop. The fitted models can be used for better prediction and prevention of street crimes. 

Some other applications of our methodology include modeling dynamic emotional patterns of smokers, bidding patterns of users that participated in eBay online auctions, and posting behaviors of social media users. These applications not only demonstrate the usefulness of the new methodologies but also lead to various new scientific findings. The project benefits the society by advancing knowledge in aforementioned scientific fields.


Last Modified: 10/28/2021
Modified by: Yongtao Guan
